page.title: List of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2013

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}}
{{Use American English|date=May 2016}} The following is a '''list of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2013'''. It is one of several [[list of pipeline accidents in the United States|lists of U.S. pipeline accidents]]. See also [[list of natural gas and oil production accidents in the United States]]. {{expand list|date=April 2013}} __NOTOC__ <!--begin temporary compact toc--> <!-- something nicer-looking and more navigable should be done here; this is a temporary TOC to ease navigation --> <!-- | bgcolor=#dddddd align=center colspan=11 | See also – [[#References|References]] --> <!--end compact toc-->
== Incidents ==
This is not a complete list of all pipeline accidents. '''For natural gas alone''', the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA), a United States Department of Transportation agency, has collected data on more than 3,200 accidents deemed serious or significant since 1987.
A "significant incident" results in any of the following consequences: * fatality or injury requiring in-patient hospitalization * $50,000 or more in total costs, measured in 1984 dollars * liquid releases of five or more barrels (42 US gal/barrel) * releases resulting in an unintentional fire or explosion
PHMSA and the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) post incident data and results of investigations into accidents involving pipelines that carry a variety of products, including natural gas, oil, diesel fuel, gasoline, kerosene, jet fuel, carbon dioxide, and other substances. Occasionally pipelines are repurposed to carry different products.<ref>Data sets of PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 1986-2001, 2002-2009, and 2010-2017 can be downloaded from the tab by that name on the PHMSA's Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10. PHMSA Corrective Action Orders are at https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/CAO_opid_0.html. PHMSA Pipeline Failure Investigation Reports are at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/safety-reports/pipeline-failure-investigation-reports. NTSB Pipeline Accident Reports are at https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/pipeline.aspx.</ref>
=== 2013 === * On January 1, a [[Colonial Pipeline]] line was overpressured by improper operation, causing a spill of about 5,500 gallons of petroleum product in [[Greensboro, North Carolina]]. About 1,000 gallons of product was not recovered.<ref name="dot5">{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_2552.html?nocache=7343#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications – Operator Information |author= |date= |work=dot.gov |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307113746/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_2552.html?nocache=7343 |archivedate=March 7, 2016 }}</ref> * On January 15, a utility crew struck and ruptured a 4-inch gas pipeline in [[Lewisville, Texas]], causing a nearby house to explode later on. The explosion killed a man.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/community-news/lewisville-flower-mound/headlines/20130115-investigation-of-deadly-lewisville-explosion-continues.ece |title=Investigation of deadly Lewisville explosion continues |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021015808/http://www.dallasnews.com/news/community-news/lewisville-flower-mound/headlines/20130115-investigation-of-deadly-lewisville-explosion-continues.ece |archivedate=October 21, 2014 }}</ref> * An independent contractor installing fiber-optic cable for a cable company in [[Kansas City, Missouri]] inadvertently struck an underground gas line on February 19. Gas later caught fire, and created an explosion that destroyed a popular local restaurant, killing one of the workers there, and injuring about 15 others near the scene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.multichannel.com/cable-operators/cable-contractor-involved-kc-gas-explosion/141835 |title=Cable Contractor Involved in KC Gas Explosion |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028112645/http://www.multichannel.com/cable-operators/cable-contractor-involved-kc-gas-explosion/141835 |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/2013/08/15/4412750/osha-cites-drilling-company-restaurant.html |title=OSHA cites drilling company in fatal explosion at JJ's restaurant |work=kansascity |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203080901/http://www.kansascity.com/2013/08/15/4412750/osha-cites-drilling-company-restaurant.html |archivedate=December 3, 2013 }}</ref> * A tug towing a barge struck and ruptured a [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] LPG pipeline at [[Bayou Perot]], a marshy area on the borders of [[Jefferson Parish, Louisiana|Jefferson Parish]] and [[Lafourche Parish, Louisiana]] on March 12. The tug Captain was severely burned when the escaping gas ignited, and died several weeks later from those injuries.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/13/us-coastguard-idUSBRE92C0YB20130313 |agency=Reuters |title=Fire erupts after tug hits Chevron LPG pipeline: Coast Guard |date=March 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130326114349/https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/13/us-coastguard-idUSBRE92C0YB20130313 |archivedate=March 26, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2013/04/11/Tug-captain-dies-of-burns-sustained-in-Louisiana-gas-explosion/UPI-68731365703619/ |title=Tug captain Chad Breaux dies of burns after Louisiana gas explosion |work=UPI |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2013/04/11/Tug-captain-dies-of-burns-sustained-in-Louisiana-gas-explosion/UPI-68731365703619/ |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * On March 8, pipeline equipment failure resulted in a spill of 6,000 barrels of crude oil, in eastern [[Columbia County, Arkansas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.magnoliareporter.com/news_and_business/local_business/article_7203fa0e-1ae8-11e6-bcb6-dbbaed627cc2.html |title=Settlement reached in 2013 Columbia County case of 6,000-barrel oil spill from pipeline |author= |date= |work=Magnolia Reporter – Magnolia, Arkansas News |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160521041650/http://www.magnoliareporter.com/news_and_business/local_business/article_7203fa0e-1ae8-11e6-bcb6-dbbaed627cc2.html |archivedate=May 21, 2016 }}</ref> * On March 18, a [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] 8-inch petroleum products pipeline ruptured along a seam, spilling diesel fuel into [[Willard Bay]] State Park near [[Ogden, Utah]]. Wildlife was coated with diesel, but the fuel was prevented from entering into water supply intakes. About 25,000 gallons of diesel were spilled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/news/56068519-78/state-pipeline-willard-diesel.html.csp |title=Utah Local News – Salt Lake City News, Sports, Archive – The Salt Lake Tribune |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020114840/http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/news/56068519-78/state-pipeline-willard-diesel.html.csp |archivedate=October 20, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=CPF No. 5-2013-5006H |url=http://phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/520135006H_cao_03222013.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170125195210/http://phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/520135006H_cao_03222013.pdf# |archivedate=January 25, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * A [[Williams Companies]] 24-inch gas gathering pipeline failed in [[Marshall County, West Virginia]] on March 22. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/03/22/gas-pipeline-explosion-idUKL1N0CE9MO20130322 |agency=Reuters |title=UPDATE 1-Williams natgas line ruptures in West Virginia |date=March 22, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028000715/http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/03/22/gas-pipeline-explosion-idUKL1N0CE9MO20130322 |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref> * The [[2013 Mayflower oil spill]] occurred when [[ExxonMobil]]'s 20-inch Pegasus crude oil pipeline spilled near [[Mayflower, Arkansas]] on March 29, causing crude to flow through yards and gutters, and towards [[Lake Conway]]. Wildlife was coated in some places. Twenty-two houses were evacuated, due to the fumes and fire hazard. Some estimates say the total amount spilled could reach upwards of 300,000 gallons of [[diluted bitumen]] were spilled. Hook cracks and extremely low impact toughness in the LF-[[Electric resistance welding|ERW]] seam of the pipe were identified as causes of the failure.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/09/rachel-maddow-mayflower-oil-spill-exxon_n_3047331.html?ir=Green |work=Huffington Post |first=Nick |last=Visser |title=Maddow Slams Exxon's 'Paper Towel' Cleanup Efforts |date=April 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130412104754/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/09/rachel-maddow-mayflower-oil-spill-exxon_n_3047331.html?ir=Green |archivedate=April 12, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://arkansasmatters.com/fulltext?nxd_id=649812 |title=Web Extra: Background on Pipeline that Ruptured Near Mayflower |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130410125438/http://arkansasmatters.com/fulltext?nxd_id=649812 |archivedate=April 10, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/File/4%202013%205006H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_4%2002%2013.pdf]{{dead link|date=May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thv11.com/news/article/271392/2/Exxon-Cause-of-pipeline-failure--manufacturing-defects |title=Exxon: Cause of pipeline failure 'manufacturing defects' |author= |date=July 10, 2013 |website=Thv11.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028010051/http://www.thv11.com/news/article/271392/2/Exxon-Cause-of-pipeline-failure--manufacturing-defects |archivedate=October 28, 2013}}</ref> * On April 4, an explosion and fire occurred at a gas compressor station near [[Guthrie, Oklahoma]]. Nearby houses were evacuated. There were no injuries reported.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.koco.com/news/oklahomanews/okc/Employee-ran-1-mile-to-escape-Guthrie-natural-gas-explosion/-/11777584/19629714/-/ols82jz/-/index.html |title=Employee ran 1 mile to escape Guthrie natural gas explosion |work=koco |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028110217/http://www.koco.com/news/oklahomanews/okc/Employee-ran-1-mile-to-escape-Guthrie-natural-gas-explosion/-/11777584/19629714/-/ols82jz/-/index.html |archivedate=October 28, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * A flash fire at a pipeline gas compressor station broke out when natural gas liquids ignited in [[Tyler County, West Virginia]] on April 11, seriously burning three workers, two of whom later died. The workers were performing pipeline pigging operations.<ref>[http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/af39190844784b7eac485e85c9b9522d/WV--Gas-Explosion]{{dead link|date=May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtov9.com/news/news/2nd-worker-dies-result-tyler-co-pipeline-explosion/nXNHz/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=April 16, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130714111743/http://www.wtov9.com/news/news/2nd-worker-dies-result-tyler-co-pipeline-explosion/nXNHz/ |archivedate=July 14, 2013}}</ref> * On April 30, the Pegasus oil pipeline spilled a small amount of crude into a residential yard in Ripley County, Missouri, a month after the same pipe spewed thousands of barrels of crude in Arkansas. The Pegasus pipeline was out of service from the [[Mayflower, Arkansas]] spill, accounting for the minimal amount of oil spilled in Missouri.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/01/exxon-pipeline-spill-idUSL2N0DI14U20130501 |agency=Reuters |title=Exxon says Missouri oil spills from already-ruptured Pegasus line |date=May 1, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924180945/https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/01/exxon-pipeline-spill-idUSL2N0DI14U20130501 |archivedate=September 24, 2015 }}</ref> * On May 9, diesel fuel was detected to be leaking from a Marathon pipeline in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]]. Over 20,000 gallons of diesel leaked, at a slow rate that was not detected by SCADA systems. Cleanup caused a nearby major road to be shut down for five days. There were no injuries reported.<ref>{{cite web|title=Report: Copper wire to blame for 2013 20K-gallon pipeline leak on nor… |url=http://www.theindychannel.com/news/call-6-investigators/report-copper-wire-to-blame-for-2013-20k-gallon-pipeline-leak-on-northwest-side |website=archive.is |accessdate=28 November 2016 |date=28 November 2016 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20161128012639/http://www.theindychannel.com/news/call-6-investigators/report-copper-wire-to-blame-for-2013-20k-gallon-pipeline-leak-on-northwest-side |archivedate=November 28, 2016 |df= }}</ref> * Late night on May 14, an explosion and fire hit a [[Williams Companies]] gas compressor station near [[Brooklyn Township, Pennsylvania]]. There were no reported injuries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wbng.com/news/local/Late-night-gas-compression-explosion-207490961.html |title=DEP: Compressor stations shows signs of explosion |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220130422/http://www.wbng.com/news/local/Late-night-gas-compression-explosion-207490961.html |archivedate=February 20, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * On May 8, the Kinder Morgan Tejas pipeline compressor station near Crockett, Texas, required an emergency shutdown and subsequently had a fire that caused $7,502,188 in property damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/StatePages/Texas.htm |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications |website=Primis.phmsa.dot.gov |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141221194813/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/StatePages/Texas.htm |archivedate=December 21, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://alerts.skytruth.org/report/05f2642d-8a93-3b6f-bbac-9c57a37b |title=Skytruth Alert: NRC Report: Natural Gas near Crockett, TX 2013-05-08 |work=SkyTruth Alerts |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813133342/http://alerts.skytruth.org/report/05f2642d-8a93-3b6f-bbac-9c57a37b |archivedate=August 13, 2014 }}</ref> * On May 18, a 24-inch fill line failed, on an [[Enbridge]] tank, in [[Cushing, Oklahoma]], spilling about 105,000 gallons of crude oil. The cause was internal corrosion of the line.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles//PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/Enbridge_2013_05_17.pdf|title=Failure Investigation Report – Enbridge Pipelines, LLC, Tank 3013 24-inch Fill Line failure in Cushing, OK|publisher=}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * On May 30, two construction workers were injured, when a fire erupted during welding at a [[Williams Companies]] natural gas facility in [[Hunterdon County, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mycentraljersey.com/article/20130530/NJNEWS/305300063/?gcheck=1 |title=News – MyCentralJersey.com – mycentraljersey.com |work=MyCentralJersey.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024102014/http://www.mycentraljersey.com/article/20130530/NJNEWS/305300063/?gcheck=1 |archivedate=October 24, 2014}}</ref> * A 12-inch gas transmission pipeline failed near [[Torrington, Wyoming]] on June 13. LF-[[Electric resistance welding|ERW]] seam failure was suspected as cause. There was no fire or injuries.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 5-2013-1007H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/520131007H/520131007H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_06192013_text.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170218004152/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/Comm/reports/enforce/documents/520131007H/520131007H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_06192013_text.pdf |archivedate=February 18, 2017 }}</ref> * On June 18, in Washington Parish, Louisiana, a [[Kinder Morgan]] Florida Gas Transmission Company 30" diameter pipeline ruptured and exploded before dawn, jolting residents out of their beds. No one was seriously hurt but 55 homes were evacuated. The blast knocked down trees in an area about 200 yards across and the fire burned those within another 300 yards. "The ground around the crater is completely bare. The dirt around it is just like it had been cooked in a kiln," and an 80-foot section of pipe was destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gas line explosion rattles Washington Parish {{!}} Home {{!}} The Advocate — … |url=http://theadvocate.com/home/6283023-125/gas-pipeline-explosion-in-franklinton |website=archive.is |accessdate=28 November 2016 |date=3 October 2014 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141003145848/http://theadvocate.com/home/6283023-125/gas-pipeline-explosion-in-franklinton |archivedate=October 3, 2014 |df= }}</ref> * On July 4, a fire involved a gas compressor and a nearby ruptured 2-inch gas pipeline in [[Gilmore Township, Pennsylvania]]. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.observer-reporter.com/article/20130705/NEWS02/130709662/-1/NEWS#.Uf3z46y0SB8 |title=Observer-Reporter – Blaze hits compressor station in Gilmore Township |work=Observer-Reporter |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020213054/http://www.observer-reporter.com/article/20130705/NEWS02/130709662/-1/NEWS#.Uf3z46y0SB8#.Uf3z46y0SB8 |archivedate=October 20, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * An 8-inch natural gas pipeline released gas from a rupture at 1,400 psi, for 90 minutes in [[New Franklin, Ohio]] on July 22, forcing 75 people to evacuate the area. Afterward, the local Fire Chief said that pipeline owners refused to give information to first responders in previous requests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ohio.com/news/city-not-privy-to-pipeline-locations-inside-own-borders-1.418507 |title=City not privy to pipeline locations inside own borders |author=Kathy Antoniotti |work=www.ohio.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023135458/http://www.ohio.com/news/city-not-privy-to-pipeline-locations-inside-own-borders-1.418507 |archivedate=October 23, 2014 }}</ref> * Early on July 23, a downed 13,000 volt power line sparked a massive gas fire in [[Mamaroneck, New York]] when a gas main was damaged by the electricity. Three automobiles were destroyed, and houses were threatened for a time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2013/07/23/fire-crews-battle-blaze-in-mamaroneck/ |title=Downed Wires Lead To Car Fires, Ruptured Gas Line In Mamaroneck " CBS New York |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919122910/http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2013/07/23/fire-crews-battle-blaze-in-mamaroneck/ |archivedate=September 19, 2015 }}</ref> * On July 26, a leaking [[BP]] 20-inch crude oil pipeline spilled 50 to 100 barrels of crude oil in [[Washington County, Oklahoma]]. Some of the crude spilled into a drainage ditch leading to a water reservoir.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newson6.com/story/22944566/crews-working-to-halt-bp-pipeline-leak-in-washington-county |title=Crews Work To Contain BP Pipeline Leak In Osage County |date=July 26, 2013 |work=newson6.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://www.newson6.com/story/22944566/crews-working-to-halt-bp-pipeline-leak-in-washington-county |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * On the evening of August 12, a 10-inch NGL pipeline exploded and caused a massive propane-ethane mix fire in [[Erie, Illinois]]. A number of nearby residents were evacuated for a while, but there were no injuries. About 772,000 gallons of mix were burned or lost. The cause was from a manufacturing defect.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31618.html?nocache=6119#_Incidents_tab_5 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Operator Information |work=dot.gov |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161227132036/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_31618.html?nocache=6119 |archivedate=December 27, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://thinkprogress.org/natural-gas-pipeline-causes-cornfield-to-explode-in-western-illinois-df1277613184#.irjwewihn|title=Natural Gas Pipeline Causes Cornfield To Explode In Western Illinois|first=Ryan|last=Koronowski|date=August 13, 2013|work=thinkprogress.org}}</ref> * A leak developed on a valve on [[Longhorn Pipeline]] in [[Austin, Texas]] during maintenance on August 14, spilling about 300 gallons of crude oil. There were no evacuations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.keyetv.com/news/features/top-stories/stories/pipeline-releases-oil-circle-c-neighborhood-11233.shtml |title=Search Results – KEYE-TV Austin |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130827010346/http://www.keyetv.com/news/features/top-stories/stories/pipeline-releases-oil-circle-c-neighborhood-11233.shtml |archivedate=August 27, 2013}}</ref> * Atmos Energy crews dug into a 4-inch gas pipeline in [[Overland Park, Kansas]] on September 2, causing an explosion and fire. There was no major damage or injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox4kc.com/2013/09/21/update-to-gas-explosion-in-overland-park/ |title=Update to gas explosion in Overland Park |work=fox4kc.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021045317/http://fox4kc.com/2013/09/21/update-to-gas-explosion-in-overland-park/ |archivedate=October 21, 2014 }}</ref> * A 10-inch gas gathering pipeline ruptured and burned in [[Newton County, Texas]] on September 21. About a dozen people from nearby houses were evacuated for a time. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/article/Gas-line-not-yet-repaired-after-explosion-in-Buna-4838918.php |title=Gas line not yet repaired after explosion in Buna |work=Beaumont Enterprise |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020224732/http://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/article/Gas-line-not-yet-repaired-after-explosion-in-Buna-4838918.php |archivedate=October 20, 2014 }}</ref> * On September 24, a Denton TX city water utility worker ruptured a 1/2-inch gas pipeline in [[Denton, Texas]], which immediately caused a fire that gave the worker minor burns. There was no other significant damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dentonrc.com/local-news/local-news-headlines/20130924-city-worker-hits-gas-line.ece |title=City worker hits gas line |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923213624/http://www.dentonrc.com/local-news/local-news-headlines/20130924-city-worker-hits-gas-line.ece |archivedate=September 23, 2015 }}</ref> * A farmer near [[Tioga, North Dakota]] smelled oil for several days, before discovering a leaking 6-inch 20-year-old [[Tesoro]] pipeline under his wheat field, on September 29. Crews tried to burn off the oil at first. The spill size was estimated at 865,000 gallons, and covered over seven acres. There were no injuries. Corrosion was suspected as being the cause. Governor Jack Dalrymple said he wasn't told of the spill until October 9. In May 2014, it was announced that it would 2 1/2 more years before the spilled crude would be cleaned up.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/corrosion-may-led-north-dakota-pipeline-leak-regulator-185854060--finance.html |title=Corrosion may have led to North Dakota pipeline leak: regulator |date=October 11, 2013 |work=Yahoo! News |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023215903/http://news.yahoo.com/corrosion-may-led-north-dakota-pipeline-leak-regulator-185854060--finance.html |archivedate=October 23, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenfieldreporter.com/view/story/121ae083847f4744a934a459c9e0d09d/ND--ND-Pipeline-Break-Cleanup |title=Archived copy |accessdate=June 14, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150615215044/http://www.greenfieldreporter.com/view/story/121ae083847f4744a934a459c9e0d09d/ND--ND-Pipeline-Break-Cleanup |archivedate=June 15, 2015}}</ref> * On October 7, a gas pipeline burst in [[Howard County, Texas]]. There was no fire, but dangerous hydrogen sulfide in the gas forced evacuations of nearby residents. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newswest9.com/story/23630636/officials-working-pipeline-explosion-in-howard-county |title=No Injuries Reported After Pipeline Explosion in Howard County |date=October 7, 2013 |work=newswest9.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://www.newswest9.com/story/23630636/officials-working-pipeline-explosion-in-howard-county |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * On October 7, authorities were notified of a Lion Oil Trading and Transportation crude oil pipeline leak in [[Columbia County, Arkansas]]. It was estimated that the leak started on September 21. Oil spread into a Horsehead Creek tributary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.magnoliareporter.com/news_and_business/local_news/article_af1148dc-32b2-11e3-b1ce-001a4bcf887a.html|title=(With video and three photos) Oil spill cleanup continues along Horsehead Creek tributary near Macedonia|work=Magnolia Reporter – Magnolia, Arkansas News|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref> * A 30-inch Northern Natural Gas pipeline exploded and burned in [[Harper County, Oklahoma]] on October 8. 220 feet of the pipe was ejected from the ground. Flames were seen for a number of miles, and four houses nearby were evacuated. Oklahoma Highway 283 was closed for several hours until the fire was determined to be under control and safe. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news9.com/story/23650973/resident-recalls-pipeline |title=Resident Describes Gas Line Explosion In Harper County |date=October 9, 2013 |work=news9.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126063036/http://www.news9.com/story/23650973/resident-recalls-pipeline |archivedate=January 26, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/Latest-News-Wires/2013/1009/Pipeline-explosion-shoots-flames-into-Oklahoma-sky |title=Pipeline explosion shoots flames into Oklahoma sky |author= |work=The Christian Science Monitor |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140727160959/http://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/Latest-News-Wires/2013/1009/Pipeline-explosion-shoots-flames-into-Oklahoma-sky |archivedate=July 27, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 4-2013-1016H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420131016H/420131016H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_10112013_text.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161223045225/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420131016H/420131016H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_10112013_text.pdf |archivedate=December 23, 2016 }}</ref> * On October 29, a [[Koch Industries]] 8-inch pipeline spilled about 400 barrels of crude oil near [[Smithville, Texas]]. The oil polluted a private stock pond and two overflow reservoirs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kvue.com/news/local/Officials-cleaning-up-400-barrel-oil-spill-near-Smithville-229756751.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=October 30, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031131030/http://www.kvue.com/news/local/Officials-cleaning-up-400-barrel-oil-spill-near-Smithville-229756751.html |archivedate=October 31, 2013}}</ref> * A [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] operated 10-inch LPG pipeline was ruptured by contractors for the company installing a [[Cathodic protection]] system, near [[Milford, Texas]], on November 14, causing a large fire, and forcing the evacuation of Milford and 200 students of a nearby school. A nearby 14-inch pipeline was threatened by the failure, but did not fail. There were no injuries reported. About 183,000 gallons of propane burned.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kwtx.com/home/headlines/Gas-Line-Explosion-Reported-In-Rural-Central-Texas-231914001.html?ref=001 |title=Small Town Residents Allowed To Return After Fiery Blast |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021130907/http://www.kwtx.com/home/headlines/Gas-Line-Explosion-Reported-In-Rural-Central-Texas-231914001.html?ref=001 |archivedate=October 21, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2013/11/14/energy-pipeline-explosion-idINL2N0IZ1F320131114 |agency=Reuters |title=UPDATE 4-Chevron pipeline explodes, burns in rural Texas |date=November 14, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212133736/http://in.reuters.com/article/2013/11/14/energy-pipeline-explosion-idINL2N0IZ1F320131114 |archivedate=December 12, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF 4-2014-5012 |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420145012/420145012_NOPV%20PCP%20PCO_05212014_text.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211164926/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420145012/420145012_NOPV%20PCP%20PCO_05212014_text.pdf |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_2731.html?nocache=116#_Incidents_tab_4 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Operator Information |work=dot.gov |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161227132020/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_2731.html?nocache=116 |archivedate=December 27, 2016 }}</ref> * An [[ExxonMobil]] gas plant exploded and burned on November 17, near [[Kingsville, Texas]]. The plant burned for over a day, but there were no reported injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kiiitv.com/story/24003322/exxonmobils-king-ranch-gas-plant-continues-burning-after-overnight-fire |title=ExxonMobil's King Ranch Gas Plant Continues Burning – KiiiTV.com South Texas, Corpus Christi, Coastal Bend |date=November 18, 2013 |work=kiiitv.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://www.kiiitv.com/story/24003322/exxonmobils-king-ranch-gas-plant-continues-burning-after-overnight-fire |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * On November 18, a gas pipeline burst near [[Ranger, Texas]], causing a fire in a field, with flames reaching 100 feet high. Some houses nearby were evacuated for a time. The owner of the pipeline, Hanlon Gas, had been installing a new compressor station, and they believe a malfunction led to the rupture and fire. There were no injuries reported.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bigcountryhomepage.com/story/gas-pipeline-rupture-send-flames-100-feet-into-air/d/story/cFdS71R_kEeMi0TUv8vasw |title=Gas Pipeline Rupture Send Flames 100 Feet Into Air |agency=Associated Press |work=BigCountryHomepage |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023113953/http://www.bigcountryhomepage.com/story/gas-pipeline-rupture-send-flames-100-feet-into-air/d/story/cFdS71R_kEeMi0TUv8vasw |archivedate=October 23, 2014}}</ref> * On November 28 a 30-inch Panhandle Eastern natural gas pipeline exploded in [[Hughesville, Missouri]] causing several nearby buildings to catch fire. There was a local evacuation but no injuries. Metallurgical examination determined the root cause of the failure to be corrosion.<ref name="dot3">{{cite web|title=CPF No. 3-2014-10088 |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320141008S/320141008S_Notice%20of%20Proposed%20Safety%20Order_12242014.pdf |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150115105300/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320141008S/320141008S_Notice%20of%20Proposed%20Safety%20Order_12242014.pdf |archivedate=January 15, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox4kc.com/2013/11/29/reported-pipeline-explosion-rocks-parts-of-missouri/ |title=Pipeline explosion sends fireball 300 feet into air |work=fox4kc.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150103231722/http://fox4kc.com/2013/11/29/reported-pipeline-explosion-rocks-parts-of-missouri/ |archivedate=January 3, 2015 }}</ref> * On December 9, a 2-inch pipe on a propane dehydrator failed at the Dixie Pipeline Terminal in [[Apex, North Carolina]], forcing evacuations and sheltering in place at nearby businesses. There was no fire or explosion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wncn.com/story/24171804/gas-line-leak-reported-in-apex |title=Archived copy |accessdate=December 10, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213094441/http://www.wncn.com/story/24171804/gas-line-leak-reported-in-apex |archivedate=December 13, 2013}}</ref> * A [[Sunoco]] pipeline was found leaking gasoline on December 20, near [[Coal Township, Pennsylvania]], from external corrosion. About 266 to 471 gallons of product were spilled, and, 1,421 tons of soil were removed, as part of the remediation of that leak.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsitem.com/news/2017-07-29/Today's_Top_Stories/Sunoco_fined_65000_for_pipeline_leak.html|title=News-Item|website=News-Item}}</ref> * On December 27, two natural gas company workers had minor burns when the pipeline they were working leaked, and the escaping gas exploded and ignited in [[Shrewsbury, Massachusetts]]. Flames 30 feet high knocked out phone service in the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegram.com/article/20131227/NEWS/312279749/1116 |title=Crews respond to gas-line fire in Shrewsbury |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020142812/http://www.telegram.com/article/20131227/NEWS/312279749/1116 |archivedate=October 20, 2014 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}} {{List of pipeline accidents in the United States|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Lists of pipeline accidents in the United States]]

This article is a '''list of diseases''' of the [[sweet potato]], (''Ipomoea batatas''). ==Bacterial diseases== {| class="wikitable" ! colspan=2| Bacterial diseases |- | Bacter | ''[[Erwinia chrysanthemi]]'' |- | Bacterial wilt | ''[[Ralstonia solanacearum]]'' |- | Crown gall | ''[[Agrobacterium tumefaciens]]'' |- | Hairy roots | ''[[Agrobacterium rhizogenes]]'' |- | Little leaf (proliferation disease) | [[Phytoplasma]] |} ==Fungal diseases== {| class="wikitable" ! colspan=2| Fungal diseases |- | Alternaria leaf spot and stem blight | ''[[Alternaria]]'' spp. |- | Alternaria storage rot | ''[[Alternaria]]'' spp. |- | [[Anthracnose]]{{Verify source|date=November 2007}} | ''[[Colletotrichum coccodes]]'' |- | Black rot | ''[[Ceratocystis fimbriata]]''

''[[Paratrichodorus minor]]'' |- |Stunt || ''[[Tylenchorhynchus]]'' spp. |- |} ==Viral and viroid diseases== {| class="wikitable" ! colspan=2| Viral and viroid diseases |- |Feathery mottle ||''Sweet potato feathery mottle virus'' (SPFMV) |- |Internal cork ||Internal cork strain of ''Sweet potato feathery mottle virus'' (SPFMV-IC) |- |Latent virus ||Sweet potato latent virus (SPLV) |- |Mild mottle ||''Sweet potato mild mottle virus'' (SPMMV) |- |Russet crack ||Russet crack strain of ''Sweet potato feathery mottle virus'' (SPFMV-RC) |- |Sweet potato virus disease (SPVD) ||''Sweet potato feathery mottle virus'' and ''Sweet potato chlorotic stunt virus'' [http://www.pnas.org/content/106/25/10354] retrieved on 2009-12-1 . full |- |} == References == {{Reflist}} * [http://www.apsnet.org/publications/commonnames/Pages/Sweetpotato.aspx Common Names of Diseases, The American Phytopathological Society] * [http://www.pnas.org/content/106/25/10354.full] {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Sweet Potato Diseases}} [[Category:Lists of plant diseases|Sweet potato]] [[Category:Sweet potatoes|Diseases]] [[Category:Root vegetable diseases|Sweet potato]]

{{for|the music journalist|Mark Beaumont (journalist)}} {{Use British English|date=September 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Mark Beaumont [[British Empire Medal|BEM]] | image = Mark Beaumont - 1.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1983|1|1}} | birth_place = [[Swindon, England]] | nationality = [[Scottish people|Scottish]] | other_names = | known_for = [[Around the world cycling record|Record for cycling round the world]] | occupation = Cyclist, adventurer, broadcaster, documentary maker, author | website = {{URL|markbeaumontonline.com/}} }} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Mark-Beaumont.jpg|200px|thumb|Mark Beaumont. {{puic|Mark-Beaumont.jpg|log=2009 May 28}}]] --> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Mark-beaumont-2.JPG|200px|thumb|Beaumont as he appeared in his video diaries after several weeks on the road. {{puic|Mark-beaumont-2.JPG|log=2009 May 28}}]] --> '''Mark Ian Macleod Beaumont''' [[British Empire Medal|BEM]] (born 1 January 1983)<ref>[http://www.debretts.com/people/biographies/browse/b/26055/Mark%20Ian%20Macleod+BEAUMONT.aspx Debrett's biodata]. Retrieved 17 May 2011.</ref> is a record-breaking long-distance [[Scottish people|British]]<!-- Note: media often refer to Beaumont as Scottish, but he was actually born in England and raised in Scotland --><ref>[https://archive.is/20130830003639/http://www.winningscotlandfoundation.org/Media-Centre/News-and-Events/Mark-Beaumont-Gives-Cookery-Demonstration-For-Champions-in-Schools--Video/] https://web.archive.org/web/20130526012719/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00rql0m</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmediascotland.com/media-releases/51998/mark-beaumont-team-first-over-the-line-at-the-artemis-great-kindrochit-quadrathlon/|title=Media Release: Mark Beaumont team first over the line at the Artemis Great Kindrochit Quadrathlon|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brechinadvertiser.co.uk/news/local-headlines/mark-beaumont-completes-cross-scotland-challenge-1-2965616|title=Mark Beaumont completes cross Scotland challenge|publisher=}}</ref> cyclist, adventurer, broadcaster, documentary maker and author. He holds the [[Around the world cycling record|record for cycling round the world]], completing his {{convert|18,000|mi|km|adj=on}} route on 18 September 2017, having taken less than 79 days. On 18 February 2010 Beaumont completed a quest to cycle the Americas,<ref>{{cite web|author=Mark Smith |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/home-news/scot-completes-his-nine-month-cycle-from-alaska-to-argentina-1.1007642 |title=Scot completes his nine-month cycle from Alaska to Argentina |publisher=Heraldscotland.com |date=18 February 2010 |accessdate=19 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002201647/http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/home-news/scot-completes-his-nine-month-cycle-from-alaska-to-argentina-1.1007642 |archivedate=2 October 2012 }}</ref> cycling from [[Anchorage, Alaska]], US to [[Ushuaia]] in Southern Argentina, for a [[BBC Television]] series.<ref>[http://www.pedallingaround.com/start/ Web Site for the Round-the-World Record Attempt] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821044636/http://www.pedallingaround.com/start/ |date=21 August 2008 }}</ref>
In the summer of 2011 Beaumont joined a six-man team to row from [[Resolute Bay]] in the [[Nunavut Territory]], Canada to the 1996 location of the [[North Magnetic Pole]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rowtothepole.com/ |title=Old Pulteney Row to the Pole |publisher=Rowtothepole.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110823102017/http://www.rowtothepole.com/ |archivedate=23 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Each of these expeditions was filmed for [[BBC One]] documentaries. On 1 February 2012 Beaumont and his team of rowers were rescued from the Atlantic Ocean when their rowing boat capsized during a crossing from [[Morocco]] to [[Barbados]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://blogs.independent.co.uk/2012/02/23/atlantic-odyssey-exclusive-first-hand-account-of-how-a-world-record-attempt-ended-in-near-disaster/ |title=Atlantic Odyssey: Exclusive first hand account of how a world record attempt ended in near disaster | Mark Beaumont | Independent Editor's choice Blogs |publisher=Blogs.independent.co.uk |date=2012-02-23 |accessdate=2012-07-19 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120729090528/http://blogs.independent.co.uk/2012/02/23/atlantic-odyssey-exclusive-first-hand-account-of-how-a-world-record-attempt-ended-in-near-disaster/ |archivedate=29 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 21 May 2015 he rode from Cairo to Cape Town (10,000 km) and broke the world record for fastest solo ride for the length of Africa by finishing in 42 days and 8 hours.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-32839837|title=Mark Beaumont breaks Africa cycling world record|date=21 May 2015|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=19 July 2015}}</ref> {{TOC limit|2}}
== Personal life == Beaumont was [[Homeschooling|home-schooled]] until the age of 11 by his mother, Una. He was then educated at the [[High School of Dundee]]. At age 15,<ref>{{cite news|title=Round the world cyclist Mark Beaumont in Morecambe|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/lancashire/hi/things_to_do/newsid_8557000/8557481.stm|accessdate=15 May 2011|newspaper=BBC News |date=9 March 2010}}</ref> he completed a solo ride the length of Great Britain from [[John o'Groats to Land's End]].
He has a degree in politics from the [[University of Glasgow]].<ref name="timesonline1">[http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article4559764.ece Review – "The Man who Cycled the World"]. ''The Times'' {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617012622/http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article4559764.ece |date=17 June 2011 }}</ref> He was awarded Graduate of the Year 2009 from the University of Glasgow, and won the 2010 [[Glenfiddich Spirit of Scotland Awards|Glenfiddich Spirit of Scotland Award]]. In 2012 he was awarded the degree of [[Honorary degree|Doctor of Laws honoris causa]] from the [[University of Dundee]]. Beaumont was made Rector of the [[University of Dundee]] in January 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-tayside-central-35399504|title=Dundee University names new rector|author=|date=18 September 2017|publisher=|accessdate=18 September 2017|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
In the [[2018 New Year Honours]], Beaumont was awarded the [[British Empire Medal]] (BEM) "for services to sport, broadcasting and charity."<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=62150|date=30 December 2017 |page=N26 |supp=y|nolink=y}}</ref>
== Guinness world record == [[File:Mark Beaumont - 2.jpg|thumb|right]] [[File:Bike ridden by Mark Beaumont during Americas cycle - 01.jpg|thumb|right|Bike ridden by Beaumont during Americas cycle]] [[File:Mark Beaumont carrying the olympic torch - 01.jpg|thumb|right|Beaumont carrying the Olympic torch]] [[File:Mark Beaumont's bicycle.jpg|thumb|Beaumont's Cairo to Cape Town bicycle]] In 2008, Beaumont successfully broke the [[Around the world cycling record|world record for a circumnavigational bike tour of the World]]. To qualify for the [[Guinness World Records|Guinness world record]] Beaumont was required to travel an 18,000-mile route that passes through two approximately [[antipodes|antipodal]] points. The route began and ended in [[Paris]], France, riding through 20 countries across Europe, the Middle East, India, Asia, [[Australasia]] and North America. The bicycle used for the attempt was a [[Koga-Miyata]]<ref>[http://www.pedallingaround.com/equipment/ Web Site for the Round-the-World Record Attempt] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517145246/http://www.pedallingaround.com/equipment/ |date=17 May 2008 }}</ref> with a [[Rohloff Speedhub|Rohloff internal gearing hub]]. The bike was loaded with {{convert|66|lb|kg}} of equipment such as tools, cameras and other equipment to support him during the journey. The new record was set at 194 days and 17 hours beating the previous record of 276 days and 19 hours<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Around_the_world_cycling_record#Mark_Beaumont_(2008)|website=Wikipedia|title=Around the world cycling record}}</ref>.
Beaumont endured many hardships during his voyage. In [[Lafayette, Louisiana]] he was involved in a collision with a car and robbed later the same day, and elsewhere struggled with illnesses such as [[dysentery]].
As a result of breaking the world record, Beaumont raised £18,000 for charity.
Beaumont's video diaries of the journey formed the basis of a [[BAFTA]]-nominated documentary,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/scotland/awards/bafta-scotland-awards-2008,1142,BA.html |title=BAFTA Nomination for David Peat's documentary |publisher=Bafta.org |accessdate=19 September 2011}}</ref> ''The Man who Cycled the World'', which was broadcast by the [[BBC]] in August 2008.<ref name="timesonline1"/>
Beaumont's around-the-world cycling record was broken by [[Vin Cox]] on 1 August 2010.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/cycling/7921388/British-man-sets-new-round-the-world-cycle-record.html |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Alastair | last=Jamieson | title=British man sets new round-the-world cycle record | date=1 August 2010}}</ref> Beaumont regained the [[Around the world cycling record|Guinness around-the-world cycling record]] in 2017 (see 'Around the World in 80 days' below)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Around_the_world_cycling_record#Mark_Beaumont_(2017)|website=Wikipedia|title=Around the world cycling record}}</ref>.
== BBC – ''Cycling the Americas'' == Beaumont cycled from Anchorage, Alaska, US to Ushuaia in Southern Argentina, arriving on 18 February 2010. In addition to cycling {{convert|13080|mi|km|0}} in 268 days, he climbed the highest peaks in [[North America|North]] and South America: [[Mount McKinley|Denali]] and [[Mount Aconcagua|Aconcagua]]. Along with commenting online throughout the journey, he recorded the adventure for a BBC One documentary series, ''The Man Who Cycled The Americas''. The first in the series of three episodes was broadcast on Tuesday, 23 March 2010 on BBC One. Beaumont bypassed Colombia and the [[Darien Gap]] on his journey.
==Around the World in 80 Days== During Summer 2017, Beaumont completed a second global circumnavigation, similar to his first 10 years prior, known as the ''Around the World in 80 Days Artemis Challenge''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artemisworldcycle.com |title=Artemis Around the World in 80 Days Challenge |publisher=artemisworldcycle.com |date= |accessdate=2017-08-04}}</ref>
The intention was to complete the trip in 80 days,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-39479386|title=Cyclist Mark Beaumont targets around the world in 80 days|date=2017-04-03|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-04-03|language=en-GB}}</ref> inspired by the [[Jules Verne]] story ''[[Around the World in Eighty Days]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artemisworldcycle.com/the-challenge/around-the-world-in-80-days/ |title=Artemis Around the World in 80 Days Challenge: About the Challenge |publisher=artemisworldcycle.com |date= |accessdate=2017-08-04}}</ref> A support team traveled with him on his journey, providing nutritional, mechanical and logistical support. His target was to cover approximately {{convert|240|miles|km}} a day.<ref name=bbc_41308524/> He completed the journey one day ahead of schedule on 18 September, with a total time of 78 days, 14 hours, 40 minutes. This beat the previous around-the-world cycling record by 44 days.<ref name=bbc_41308524>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-tayside-central-41308524|title=Cyclist Mark Beaumont breaks around the world record|work=BBC News|date=18 September 2017|accessdate=18 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/MrMarkBeaumont?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor|title=Officially made it round the world|publisher=Mark Beaumont (via Twitter)|accessdate=18 September 2017}}</ref>
As with Beaumonts original (2008) route, the trip started and finished in Paris, France, crossing Russia and Mongolia to Beijing, China (a more northerly route than in 2008), before echoing his original route across Australia and New Zealand. The route across North America was also a longer, more northerly route, before a final leg from Lisbon, Portugal back to Paris. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artemisworldcycle.com/the-route/|title=Artemis World Cycle - Live Tracker Map|website=www.artemisworldcycle.com}}</ref>
==Ocean rowing== During the summer of 2011, Beaumont joined a team of six in rowing through the [[Northern Canada|Canadian Arctic]], as the BBC cameraman as well as on the oars. Their aim was to reach a 1996 location of the North Magnetic Pole. It is only in the last few years that the sea ice has melted enough for such a route to be attempted.
In early 2012, Beaumont joined another team in an attempt to break the world record for rowing across the Atlantic Ocean. After 27 days and over 2,000 miles into the expedition, they capsized and had to be rescued.
==Other endeavours== In addition to being an accomplished cyclist, Beaumont is a [[skiing|skier]] and [[rowing (sport)|rower]]. In June 2009, he planned to participate in a 12-strong team attempt to row across the North Atlantic in a record-breaking 45 days. The team would have been led by [[Edinburgh]] stockbroker turned adventurer [[Leven Brown]] whose 14-man La Mondiale crew had beaten the record from the [[Canary Islands|Canaries]] to Barbados.<ref>[http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/features/Cycling-hero-Mark-Beaumont-to.4795984.jp from Edinburgh's Evening News.] Retrieved 20 December 2008.</ref> However, the boat he was going to use sank in the Atlantic Ocean.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/scotsol/homepage/news/article2425974.ece |title=Cycling hero Mark takes on the Americas |publisher=the Scottish Sun |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=19 September 2011}}</ref>
Beaumont was the first [[Olympic torch#Torches|torchbearer]] for day 26 of the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] torch relay.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18422553 | work=BBC News | title=In pictures: Olympic torch relay day 26 | date=13 June 2012}}</ref>
In September 2012, Beaumont planned to lead the World Cycle Challenge – the first fully supported group circumnavigation of the globe, with the aim of cycling {{convert|18010|mi|km|0}} in 245 days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://worldcyclechallenge.com/|title=The World Cycle Challenge}}</ref>
In May 2015, Beaumont set a new record in his "Africa Solo" challenge, cycling from Cairo to Cape Town in 42 days, and beating the previous record by 17 days.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cyclingweekly.co.uk/news/latest-news/mark-beaumont-sets-new-africa-cycling-world-record-173145|publisher=[[Cycling Weekly]]|title=Mark Beaumont sets new Africa cycling world record|author=Chris Marshall-Bell|date=2015-05-22}}</ref> The bike he rode for this and the subsequent North Coast 500 challenge was a Koga Solacio which is on display at [[Edinburgh Airport]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://road.cc/content/news/144912-mark-beaumont%E2%80%99s-koga-solacio-ready-cairo-cape-town-record-attempt|title=Mark Beaumont’s Koga Solacio for Cairo to Cape Town record attempt starting today|author=David Arthur|date=2015-04-10|publisher=road.cc}}</ref>
In November 2015, Beaumont set the record for completing the [[North Coast 500]] (a 518.7 mile route around Scotland) by bicycle in 37 hours 56 minutes and 44 seconds.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cyclingweekly.co.uk/news/latest-news/watch-mark-beaumonts-epic-non-stop-ride-around-the-north-of-scotland-199001|title=Watch: Mark Beaumont’s epic non-stop ride around the north of Scotland|date=2015-11-06|publisher=[[Cycling Weekly]]}}</ref> This effort was later beaten in 2016 by James McCallum, who completed the route in 31 hours.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/news/cyclist-james-mccallum-demolishes-mark-beaumont-s-north-coast-500-record-1-4159139|title=Cyclist James McCallum demolishes Mark Beaumont’s North Coast 500 record|date=2016-06-20|publisher=[[Edinburgh Evening News]]}}</ref>
==Media==
===Television=== *''[[The Man who Cycled the World]]'': A BBC documentary broadcast in August 2008. The content was based on Beaumont's video diaries of the journey. The documentary was nominated for a Scottish BAFTA. *''[[The Man Who Cycled The Americas]]'': This BBC documentary was broadcast on 10 May 2010.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00rql0m |title=BBC One – The Man Who Cycled the Americas |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2010-05-10 |accessdate=2012-07-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127035240/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00rql0m |archivedate=27 January 2012 }}</ref>
===Literature=== *''The Man who Cycled the World'': Beaumont’s first book, and the best selling cycling book in the UK for 2010 and 2011<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/The-Man-Who-Cycled-World/dp/0552158445/ref=pd_sim_b_1 |title=The Man Who Cycled The World: Amazon.co.uk: Mark Beaumont: Books |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-19}}</ref> *''The Man Who Cycled The Americas''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/The-Man-Who-Cycled-Americas/dp/0593066987 |title=The Man Who Cycled the Americas: Amazon.co.uk: Mark Beaumont: Books |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-19}}</ref> *''Africa Solo: My World Record Race from Cairo to Cape Town''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Africa-Solo-World-Record-Cairo/dp/0593076338 |title=Africa Solo: My World Record Race from Cairo to Cape Town: Amazon.co.uk: Mark Beaumont: Books |publisher=Bantam Press; UK ed. edition |date= |accessdate=2017-08-27}}</ref> *''Around the World in 80 Days: My World Record Breaking Adventure''
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{DEFAULTSORT:Beaumont, Mark}} [[Category:Scottish male cyclists]] [[Category:Touring cyclists]] [[Category:Circumnavigators of the globe]] [[Category:1983 births]] [[Category:People educated at the High School of Dundee]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Rectors of the University of Dundee]] [[Category:Recipients of the British Empire Medal]]

{{short description|Boundary between the Earth's crust and the mantle}} {{Original research|date=January 2018}} [[File:Mohomap.png|thumb|350px|World map showing the depth of the Moho.]]
The '''Mohorovičić discontinuity''' ({{IPA-sh|moxorôʋiːt͡ʃit͡ɕ|hr}}),<ref>{{cite book|first = Max | last = Mangold | title = Aussprachewörterbuch | language = German | date = 2005 | publisher = [[Dudenverlag]] |edition = 6th | location = Mannheim | isbn = 9783411040667 | p=559}}</ref> usually referred to as the '''Moho''', is the boundary between the [[Earth]]'s [[Crust (geology)|crust]] and the [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]].
Named after the pioneering [[Croats|Croatian]] [[seismologist]] [[Andrija Mohorovičić]], the Moho separates both the [[oceanic crust]] and [[continental crust]] from underlying mantle.The Mohorovičić discontinuity was first identified in 1909 by Mohorovičić, when he observed that [[seismogram]]s from [[Depth of focus (tectonics)|shallow-focus]] [[earthquake]]s had two sets of [[P-wave]]s and [[S-wave]]s, one that followed a direct path near the Earth's surface and the other [[refraction|refracted]] by a high-velocity medium.<ref name=McLeish>{{cite book |title=Geological science |author=Andrew McLeish |page=122 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rhkgwEvrVe8C&pg=PA122 |isbn=0-17-448221-3 |date=1992 |edition=2nd |publisher=[[Thomas Nelson & Sons]]}}</ref>
The Moho lies almost entirely within the [[lithosphere]]; only beneath [[mid-ocean ridge]]s does it define the lithosphere–[[asthenosphere]] boundary. The Mohorovičić discontinuity is {{convert|5|to(-)|10|km|mi|sigfig=1}} below the [[ocean floor]], and {{convert|20|to(-)|90|km|mi|sigfig=1}} beneath typical continental crusts, with an [[average]] of {{convert|35|km|mi}}.<ref name=Monroe>{{cite book |title=The changing Earth: exploring geology and evolution |author= James Stewart Monroe |author2=Reed Wicander |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jFPMa4MxwJkC&pg=PA216 |page=216 |isbn=0-495-55480-4 |edition=5th |publisher=Cengage Learning |date=2008}}</ref>
==Nature== [[File:Earth-crust-cutaway-numbered.svg|thumb|250px|Earth cross-section showing location of the Mohorovičić discontinuity (labelled as 2)]] [[File:Refraction of P-wave.PNG|thumb|250px|Two paths of a P-wave, one direct and one refracted as it crosses the Moho.<ref name=McLeish/>]] [[Image:Gros Morne moho.jpg|right|thumb|250px|[[Ordovician]] [[ophiolite]] in [[Gros Morne National Park]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]]. This rock which formed the Ordovician Moho is exposed on the surface.]] Immediately above the Moho, the [[Velocity|velocities]] of primary seismic waves (P-waves) are consistent with those through [[basalt]] (6.7–7.2 km/s), and below they are similar to those through [[peridotite]] or [[dunite]] (7.6–8.6 km/s).<ref name=Badescu>{{cite book |title=Macro-engineering: a challenge for the future |page=169 |author=RB Cathcart |author2=MM Ćirković |last-author-amp=yes |editor=Viorel Badescu |editor2=[[Richard Brook Cathcart]] |editor3=Roelof D Schuiling |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5bZBEM31K1MC&pg=PA169 |isbn=1-4020-3739-2 |date=2006 |publisher=Springer}}</ref> That suggests the Moho marks a change of composition, but the interface appears to be too even for any believable sorting mechanism{{clarify|date=December 2017}} within the Earth. Near-surface observations suggest such sorting produces an irregular surface.<ref name=Howell>{{cite book |title=An introduction to seismological research: history and development |author=Benjamin Franklin Howell |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4e1Cc-nqcGoC&pg=PA2&lpg=PA2&dq=An+introduction+to+seismological+research:+history+and+development&source=bl&ots=L1ofjy1Yqz&sig=f2EwO2WwlTHb32XSoiawslIsTq8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SpEwU7ikAoiqyAHT44Fg&ved=0CFQQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q&f=false |page=77 ''ff'' |isbn=0-521-38571-7 |date=1990 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]}}</ref>
The Moho is characterized by a transition zone of up to 500 m thick.<ref>[http://www.agu.org/books/gm/v013/GM013p0660/GM013p0660.pdf D.P. McKenzie - The Mohorovičić Discontinuity]</ref> Ancient Moho zones are exposed above-ground in numerous [[ophiolite]]s around the world.
==Exploration== During the late 1950s and early 1960s the executive committee of the U.S. [[National Science Foundation]] funded drilling a hole through the ocean floor to reach this boundary. However the operation, named [[Project Mohole]], never received sufficient support and was mismanaged{{citation needed|date=April 2014}}; the [[United States Congress]] canceled it in 1967. Soviet scientists at the [[Kola Superdeep Borehole|Kola Institute]] pursued the goal simultaneously; after 15 years they reached a depth of {{convert|12260|m|ft}}, the world's deepest hole, before abandoning their attempt in 1989.<ref> {{cite web |url= https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/multimedia/2008/08/gallery_kola_borehole |title= How the Soviets Drilled the Deepest Hole in the World |work= [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date= 2008-08-25 |accessdate= 2008-08-26}}</ref>
Reaching the discontinuity remains an important scientific objective. One proposal considers a rock-melting [[radioactive decay|radionuclide-powered]] capsule with a heavy [[tungsten]] needle that can propel itself down to the Moho discontinuity and explore [[Structure of the Earth|Earth's interior]] near it and in the upper mantle.<ref> {{cite journal |last= Ozhovan |first= M. |author2= F. Gibb |author3= P. Poluektov |author4= E. Emets |last-author-amp= yes |date= August 2005 |title= Probing of the Interior Layers of the Earth with Self-Sinking Capsules |journal= Atomic Energy |volume= 99 |issue= 2 |pages= 556–562 |doi= 10.1007/s10512-005-0246-y}} </ref> The Japanese project [[Chikyu Hakken]] ("Earth Discovery") also aims to explore in this general area with the drilling ship, ''[[Chikyū]]'', built for the [[Integrated Ocean Drilling Program]] (IODP).
Plans called for the [[drillship|drill-ship]] ''[[JOIDES Resolution]]'' to sail from [[Colombo]] in [[Sri Lanka]] in late 2015 and to head for the [[Atlantis Bank]], a promising location in the southwestern Indian Ocean on the [[Southwest Indian Ridge]], to attempt to drill an initial bore hole to a depth of approximately 1.5 kilometres.<ref> {{cite journal |last= Witze |first= Alexandra |date= December 2015 |title= Quest to drill into Earth's mantle restarts |journal= Nature News |doi=10.1038/528016a |volume=528 |pages=16–17 |bibcode=2015Natur.528...16W}} </ref> The attempt did not even reach 1.3 km, but researchers hope to further their investigations at a later date.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://joidesresolution.org/node/4399 |title = Looking Back on Expedition 360 |last1 = Kavanagh |first1 = Lucas |author-link1 = |date = 2016-01-27 |website = JOIDES Resolution |access-date = 2016-09-21 |quote = We may not have made it to our goal of 1300 m, but we did drill the deepest ever single-leg hole into hard rock (789 m), which is currently the 5th deepest ever drilled into the hard ocean crust. We also obtained both the longest (2.85 m) and widest (18 cm) single pieces of hard rock ever recovered by the International Ocean Discovery Program and its predecessors! [...] Our hopes are high to return to this site in the not too distant future. |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160709120936/http://joidesresolution.org/node/4399 |archivedate = 2016-07-09 |df = }} </ref>
